column2: 2009@Linguistic analysis in social science@It's a strange fact about social scientists that hardly any of them
column3: in recent years
column4: have paid any analytic attention to language
column5: which is the main medium of human social interaction.  At schools of "communication"
column6: you'll generally find that neither the curriculum nor the faculty's research publications feature much if any analysis of speech and language. In other disciplines — sociology
column9: history — you'll find even less of it. (The main systematic exception
column11: deserves a separate discussion — but the conclusion of such a discussion
column13: would note a steep decline in empirical linguistic analysis. And of course I'm leaving out sociolinguistics
column14: which is healthy enough but largely alienated from the rest of the social sciences.)@http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/myl/DoddsDanforthFig7.png@Language Log
